clinical_study.brief_title: Disability and Self-rated Health Following Primary Knee Replacement
clinical_study.official_title: The Effects of Primary Knee Replacement for Osteoarthritis on Disability in Activities of Daily Living and Self-rated Health in Older People

brief_summary.textblock: Knee replacement is an effective treatment in late-stage osteoarthritis. It reduces pain and improves quality of life. There is, however, limited data concerning its results in older people and on its effect on how patients survive in regular activities of daily living (ADL), such as bathing and shopping. In this study, the results of knee replacement are evaluated from the point of view of disability in everyday activities and self-rated health. Moreover, association with ADL performance and clinical knee scores and severity of osteoarthritis are assessed.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a cross-sectional study with a 12 month follow-up for recruited patients. Most data are gathered by a postal questionnaire.

primary_outcome.measure: Disability in activities of daily living

arm_group.description: Patients (aged 75 years or over) with late-stage arthritis who have undergone or are undergoing primary knee replacement

study_pop.textblock: Patients refererred to or operated on with primary knee replacement in a population-based tertiary care hospital

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- age 75 years or more at the time of operation
- diagnosis of knee osteoarthritis
- scheduled for or operated on with primary knee replacement
Exclusion Criteria:
- died during the follow-up
- inflammatory arthritides
